name: ["No Letter Challenge"] Polynomial Extrapolation
description:
# .:!:. Unpublished .:!:.
(Since this is now an "unpublished draft" and "can't be deleted", I may test some changes I had suggested...)

------

**NOTE:** This can be seen as some kind of "Challenge Mode" for [**that Kata**](https://www.codewars.com/kata/6146a6f1b117f50007d44460/haskell), which I must credit `@Kacarott` for the Haskell translation (from which "lazy me" will just plagiarize a Lot... *please forgive me*).

------

# Description:

It's your first day; and as a very first little "challenge", *the Boss* requires you to implement a basic algorithm in Haskell to extrapolate sequences... \
==> *OK that sounds fairly easy! Let's do it!..* :) 

...Wait **WHAT!??** O_o \
OH NO!! Looks like your rival Vecheata just sabotaged your computer!? D: \
Part of your keyboard is completely locked: you can no longer type any letter of the alphabet (nor use the mouse nor any kind of ASCII/"escape sequence" trick or whatever: there is just "no way to bypass it")

What an *@55h0le*! >:(

...Anyways... You can still use numbers and special characters: that should be more than enough for you, right? ;)


# Your Task:

Implement a function `_0_` that takes a sequence and a number, and returns that sequece completed with that number of elements, according to the best polynomial approximation.
(That is: for a sequence of length n, the extrapolation w.r.t. a polynomial of degree n-1)

## Examples:

```haskell
_0_ [1] 0 -- returns [1]
_0_ [1] 5 -- returns [1, 1, 1, 1, 1, 1]
_0_ [1, 4] 5 -- returns [1, 4, 7, 10, 13, 16, 19]
_0_ [1, 4, 9] 5 -- returns [1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, 49, 64]
_0_ [4, 16, 36] 5 -- returns [4, 16, 36, 64, 100, 144, 196, 256]
_0_ [216, 125, 64, 27] 7 -- returns [216, 125, 64, 27, 8, 1, 0, -1, -8, -27, -64]
```

***(see above-mentioned Kata for more details)***


# Constraint:

You are **NOT** allowed to use any of the following characters: \
abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyzABCDEFGHIJKLMNOPQRSTUVWXYZ

Have fun! :D


**Important NOTE:** The very first line of the program is the only exception; it should -obviously- remain unchanged: \
`module FckUVecheata where`
